subject: Introduce changes necessary for generic volume migration
commit_message:
Introduce changes necessary for generic volume migration

This patch contains the core driver changes needed to make generic
volume migration possible.  By itself, no changes to the existing logic
for volume migration are introduced.  The intent is to keep the original
behaviour intact while allowing certain drivers that cannot attach
volumes locally to still participate in volume migration.

To allow this functionality, an 'is_attachable' function is added to the
volume driver definition.  This property indicates whether the volume
can be attached locally to the host and expose a path to the resulting
block device.  A driver author can override this and return False if
a driver cannot attach its volumes in a way that exposes a block device
path.  Doing so will cause the volume copy routine (copy_volume_data) to
use file I/O instead of calling out to `dd`.  The driver author is
expected to provide an implementation of open_volume() that returns
a file object capable of proxying I/O requests to the underlying storage
backend.

An RPC call for 'is_attachable' is added to allow querying of remote
volume capabilities.

The default volume open and close routines are currently unimplemented
and are the next step in this series.  The open routine will return
a file handle defined by the path to the block device.  This will allow
drivers like RBD which do not support attachment to migrate to and from
drivers which do support attachment, such as LVM.

Related-Blueprint: generic-volume-migration

subject: Mask token in debug output
commit_message:
Mask token in debug output

Replaying the token in debug output is both completely burdensome to
read (given it's unbounded size), but it's also potentially a security
issue given that it could be used in replay attacks.

Instead, filter the headers to sha1 sensitive things, with X-Auth-Token
being the only one listed so far. The sha1 will at least give us the
understanding of tokens being the same or different (and an administrator
could use that to figure out if they were valid later).

This also removes some extra '\n' that were being injected into the
debug logs, because they were not helping with readability.

Lastly, actually test logging. This introduces the first tests of the
logging path using the logging fixture. It's pretty basic, but does
verify that requests are logged at debug, that the SHA1 format works,
and that headers which are not listed get shown straight through.

DocImpact because this changes the curl dumped strings which people
may have been using. They can still do that as long as they generate
their own keystone token.

(Patch and commit message inspired from Sean Dague's novaclient
implementation)

subject: Include timestamp in diskfile create
commit_message:
Include timestamp in diskfile create

In all known cases when creating a new DiskFileWriter with DiskFile.create the
final timestamp of the object to be created is known ahead of time, but not
exposed to the DiskFile implementation until the end of the write via metadata
in the call to put.

The timestamp of the newly created object is an important detail to the
default DiskFile implementation in it's handling of consistency and it's
on-disk layout; but the file system based implementation can avoid requring
this core piece of information until the very last call to the DiskFileWriter
because of the under-lying datastores support for atomic move.

For datastores which do not support atomic move (such as key value stores) it
can greatly simplify failure mode recovery if the final timestamp/version of
the object created is known before the very call to write.

With the introduction of the Timestamp class; there's a very small
simplification in the core implementation that falls out of not having to
reparse the string form of the timestamp provided in metadata to construct the
internalized timestamp used when creating the final on-disk name.

Because a new previously undescribed optional keyword is pushed into
DiskFile.create by swift.obj.server.ObjectController.PUT this change is
Backwards incompatible with existing implementations of DiskFile that did not
have the lucky foresight to accept **kwargs in their implementation of create
(e.g.  swift.obj.mem_diskfile.DiskFile.create).  When testing with the next
version of swift that includes this change diskfile maintainers who want to
continue to support the latest version will need to accept the new signature
for create but will not be required to adopt it and can maintain backwards
compatibility with older versions of swift simply by ignoring it and using the
timestamp provided in metadata as always.

Change-Id: I9d69ca26c3e590d174e3d936c2e4fd6e3acdbb74

The _select_ips_for_remote_group method was joining the
IP allocation, port, allowed address pair, and security group tables

the port columns and using none of them. This resulted in a
very expensive query with no benefit.

the IP allocation table directly to the security groups and allowed
address pairs tables. In local testing of the method, this sped it up

When NUMA placement is in effect, Nova configures KVM guest vCPUs
to be placed on certain host NUMA nodes. It also provides guest

subject: Replace six.text_type in print funcs
commit_message:
Replace six.text_type in print funcs

Functions "print_list" and "print_dict" in cliutils should not use
binary types (encoded), it should use only string types, preferred - unicode.
It is required by py3.x compatibility, to have output as following:

+-----+-----+
| foo | bar |
+-----+-----+

instead of

b'+-----+-----+\n| foo | bar |\n+-----+-----++\n

So replace encodeutils.safe_encode with six.text_type.

Why it works in py2 see following:

isinstance('foo', six.text_type)  # -> False !
isinstance('foo', six.binary_type)  # -> True !
isinstance('foo', six.string_types)  # -> True
isinstance(u'foo', six.text_type)  # -> True
isinstance(u'foo', six.binary_type)  # -> False
isinstance(u'foo', six.string_types)  # -> True

but in py3 we have:
isinstance('foo', six.text_type)  # -> True !
isinstance('foo', six.binary_type)  # -> False !
isinstance('foo', six.string_types)  # -> True
isinstance(u'foo', six.text_type)  # -> True
isinstance(u'foo', six.binary_type)  # -> False
isinstance(u'foo', six.string_types)  # -> True

Change-Id: Ia51f132f445f75d389e3cd625ba355fb0622eef5

subject: Deduplicate some INFO and AUDIT level messages
commit_message:
Deduplicate some INFO and AUDIT level messages

I'm trying to debug a problem where the last thing in the logs is
"Starting instance...".  Unfortunately this occurs twice in the same
source file, so it's hard to figure out a priori which log statement
it came from.  Audit and info messages don't disambiguate their
function/line number, all you get is the logger name like:

2014-04-06 19:51:01.871 8288 AUDIT
  nova.compute.manager [req-...] [instance: ...] Starting instance...

I think it doesn't hurt to to make sure all logs at this level are
unique, even if upstream were to log the function (see [1]).  Most
duplicate LOG.info and LOG.audit level messages are in separate files
so we can disambiguate by the name, but there are a few that overlap.

For reference, the less-then-perfect but useful check I used was:
 $ grep -r 'LOG.audit' * | sed 's/:\s*/ /' | sort -k1 | uniq -f1 -c

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/85638/

The way the merged spec described how the vendor methods will be
exposed via our API doesn't work because the 'method' to be invoked

now against evacuate function:

nova rebuild are sharing some code. When user enables
the on_shared_storage option for nova evacuate, nova

subject: Raise number of nailgun uWSGI workers and sockets
commit_message:
Raise number of nailgun uWSGI workers and sockets

Fixes issue where nailgun stops responding to requests
because all workers are occupied and the queue of
available uWSGI sockets fills up by increasing the
number of workers (double) and raising the connection
limit from 100 to 4096.

Closes-Bug: #1391935

subject: Enabling Heat provisioning based on ENV for Trove
commit_message:
Enabling Heat provisioning based on ENV for Trove

Reasons:
 - Trove can use Heat as resource delivery service.
   Heat support can be enabled by setting
   `use_heat=...` in trove-taskmanager.conf,
   in [DEFAULT] section;
 - required for bulding Trove gate with enabled Heat-provisioning.
Changes:
 - adding HEAT_PROVISIONING_SUPPORT variable in lib/trove
   that relays on ENV variable HEAT_PROVISIONING_SUPPORT;
 - if HEAT_PROVISIONING_SUPPORT is not set - use False by the default.

Depends-On: Ie0426cd0113db5f9513bafa8c0f4bd3004eaa1a1
